titleStmt.title: Anglo-tyrannus, or the idea of a Norman monarch, represented in the paralell reignes of Henrie the Third and Charles kings of England, wherein the whole management of affairs under the Norman kings is manifested, together with the real ground, and rise of all those former, and these latter contestations between the princes, and people of this nation, upon the score of prerogative and liberty. And the impious, abusive, and delusive practises are in short discovered, by which the English have been bobbed of their freedome, and the Norman tyrannie founded and continued over them. / By G.W. of Lincolnes Inne.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Anglo-Tyrannus, Or the Idea of a NORMAN MONARCH, Repre≈øented in the paralell Reignes of HENRIE the Third and CHARLES Kings of ENGLAND, Wherein the whole management of affairs under the Norman Kings is manife≈øted, together with the real ground, and ri≈øe of all tho≈øe former, and the≈øe latter conte≈øtations between the Princes, and people of this Nation, upon the ≈øcore of Prerogative and Liberty. And the impious, abu≈øive, and delu≈øive practi≈øes are in ≈øhort di≈øcovered, by which the Engli≈øh have been bobbed of their freedome, and the Norman Tyrannie founded and continued over them.
By G. W. of Lincolnes Inne.
div.q: Nihil medium Libertas habet, quae aut tota e≈øt, quod debet, aut ami≈ø≈øa parte ≈øui tota fuit, et extinguitur: Quam ideirco non ignavis, neque Brutis, & ad ≈øerviendum natis, ≈øed erectis animabus Deus immortalis con≈øervandam tradit.Hein≈øius orat. 4.

q.l: Privata bona ≈øunt, qua juvat Reges eant.

div.p: London printed for George Thomp≈øon at the Signe of the white hor≈øe in Chancery Lane. 1650.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Lord Pre≈øident BRADSHAW.
div.p:
THough I may ≈øeem bold, I am not ≈øo blind, but that I perceive your Lord≈øhip taller by the head than mo≈øt I can ≈øet by you, and ≈øo come for patronage in hopes of a favourable ≈ømile, being ≈øure to have frownes enough from them, who not able to look over the heads of others, croud as it were hood-wink'd after tho≈øe that goe before them. It was the ancient practice of en≈ølaved Rome, after death to Deifie her Tyrants, and this her badge of ≈ølavery we in England have long worn as a Livery of our bondage; who≈øe Kings (when dead) mu≈øt be of Famous, and Ble≈ø≈øed Memory, though they liv'd most infamous for Cowardize, and dete≈øtable for Tyranny; and though this was acted to flatter their Succe≈øsors at fir≈øt, yet by custome it hath ≈øo prevailed, that notwith≈øtanding the cau≈øe is now taken away, the effect remains among the multitude (to whom Logick mu≈øt give place in their irrationall actings) and from a naturall nece≈øsity is become a divine in≈øtitution; ≈øo that immortall, as earthly
Crownes are givem them Iure Divino, to dye Saints, as they live Kings: Indeed Rome may have ≈øomthing pleaded in her excu≈øe, for ≈øhe had her infernall Gods, whom by ≈øacrifice ≈øhe endeavoured to appea≈øe from doing mi≈øchief, ≈øo little inferiour was her ≈øuperstition to her ≈ølavery, which was as great as tyranny could create. I know our royall Idolaters will lay hold of the Horns of this, De mortuis nil ni≈øi bonum; but it can afford them little ≈øafety, and me le≈ø≈øe danger, whom the Metaphy≈øicks have taught, that bonum & verum convertuntur, that J cannot write good, unle≈øse J write truth; thus what they have taken for their ≈øhield, is the dart which pierceth their Liver, and by what they would ward off, they are ≈ømitten with the blow of high-trea≈øon, them≈øelves being the only and grand tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors again≈øt the maje≈øty of Hi≈øtory, who≈øe Prerogative it is not onely to reward the good, with honour and renown, but al≈øo to puni≈øh the evill, with ignominie and reproach. The ca≈øe standing thus, I am a≈ø≈øured of your Lord≈øhips protection, again≈øt all ≈øtorms ≈øuch inchantments may rai≈øe again≈øt me, who≈øe rationall eye being able to pierce the≈øe foggs doth perceive what hath ≈øo long been invelop'd in the mi≈øt.

Thus my Lord, having looked a≈øide at ≈øelfe, yet I con≈øtantly kept your Lord≈øhip in my eye,, and your honour ≈øtood fore-right, my ≈øafety but on one ≈øide in my choice, not out of pre≈øumption that my weak endeavours could adde any thing to you, but in a≈ø≈øurance that others ≈øeeing what profit they have received, what mi≈øery they have e≈øcaped in the book, will return to the Dedication,
and with honour read your name, who have been ≈øo great an iu≈øtrumet under God of their deliverance.

God hath cho≈øen you to judge between a King and a people, and your ≈øentence hath ≈øhewn you are ≈øufficiently informed of what this Di≈øcour≈øe treats: yet as a Pharos may be u≈øefull to delight a man with the pro≈øpect of tho≈øe rocks, ≈øhelves, and ≈øands he hath e≈øcaped, to whom it was a ≈øea mark to guide ≈øafe into the Port; ≈øo may your Lord≈øhip with comfort cast your eye upon the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe, viewing the dangers you and all good Patriots have pa≈øt, e≈øpecially having had ≈øo great an hand in the ≈øteerage into the Harbour.

And now give me leave to mention your worthy acts, that it may be known I am not unmindfull of a good turn, it is the onely thanks I am able to repay in the behalf of my Conntrey and ≈øelf: I know ≈øome will be apt to condemne ≈øuch an action as ≈øavouring of flatterie, but the most free from that vice, the mo≈øt ≈øevere, the mo≈øt rigid in the School of vertue, a Cato him≈øelf hath done the like, and that not onely upon the Score of gratitude, but to encourage and incite to further gallantry, and the mo≈øt cen≈øorious of them may perchance perceive their own black Shadows by your light, and from your example take out a new le≈ø≈øon of duty to their countrey whom they ought to ≈øerve before them≈øelves.

You have undauntedly ≈øtood the ≈øhock of what ever ≈ølavi≈øh malice could bring again≈øt you, and have been eminent in vindicating the right God and nature inve≈øted the nation with from
the power of u≈øurping tyranny, no counterfeit rayes, no glittering impo≈øtures gilded with pretences of ≈øacred, and Maje≈øtick have dazzeled your eyes, but with a ≈øteddy and impartiall hand you have guided the Scale of ju≈øtice, wherein that bubble of worldly honour hath been found too light to counterpoi≈øe tho≈øe ≈øinnes of murder and oppre≈øsion, which brought ≈øuch heavy judgements on the land, who≈øe yo ‚Ä¢ e hath been broken, who≈øe guilt hath been removed in a great mea≈øure, by having ju≈øtice executed without re≈øpect of per≈øons.

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øaith the Philo≈øopher, to do good to one is honourable, to a nation is heroicall; to perform the fir≈øt, is the private mans duty, to be able to do the latter is the publick magi≈øtrates divinity. God hath not onely given you power, but a mind al≈øo to employ it well, you have been good as wel as Great, and God hath pre≈øerved you, & honored you in your integrity, of which we have received ≈øuch ≈øure ≈øigns, that it must argue us more ≈øevere than ju≈øt, more ≈øu≈øpicious than Charitable, but to doubt that the Honour of God, the good and freedome of your Countrie ≈øhall not ≈øtill po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the first part of your affections, and be the ultimate end in all your actions, that ≈øo the goodwill of him that dwelt in the Bu≈øh being with you and your fellow Builders may enable you to perfect the great work of Reformation to his glory, your own honours, and the happine≈ø≈øe and freedome of this nation, all which are uufeignedly de≈øired by him who craving pardon for this bold approach as by duty obliged ≈øub≈øcribes.

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble ≈øervant George Walker.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
HE mu≈øt ri≈øe betimes (≈øaith the proverb) who will plea≈øe all, which may cea≈øe our wonder that the Common-wealth is ≈øo di≈øplea≈øant to ≈øome, which hath gotten up ≈øo late, yet better late than never. But though ≈øome dotarts ≈øquare all by antiquity, ≈øuppo≈øing none ≈øo wi≈øe, which are not ≈øo old‚ñ™ and gue≈ø≈øe at the under≈øtanding by the gray hairs, which in truth are rather a badge of imperfection, and the declen≈øion of nature, and which came into the world at the back doore, being a part of that fatall off≈øpring begot between the Serpents craft, and our fir≈øt Parents di≈øobedience: I ≈øpeak not this in ≈øcorn of age, which I honour when found in the way of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and truth, nor in deniall of its advantage over youth by experience, but to oppo≈øe that errour ≈øpred among≈øt many that all wi≈ødome decea≈øed with their Grand≈øires, and they are onely to travell in their tracks, an opinion more agreeable to a pack hor≈øe, than a man endued with a rationall ≈øoul, which is not to lie idle, and which indeed the word of God, and univer≈øall experience which even make fools wi≈øe contradicts, the one infallibly declaring that in the latter dayes the Spirit of Truth ≈øhall more abundantly be poured forth into earthen ve≈ø≈øels; the other vi≈øibly informing us of the daily advantages we have above our ancestors to attain Knowledge; for admit they were ≈øuch G ‚Ä¢ y ants in under≈øtanding, yet we poore dwarfes being upon their ≈øhoulders may ≈øee further than they: but I ≈øay though ≈øome doe thus, yet the ≈øons of rea≈øon mea≈øure by another ≈øtandard‚ñ™ as knowing that if worth ≈øhould be pri≈øed by antiquity, the rotten would becom of more value than the ripe, to ≈øuch therefore do I pre≈øent this Di≈øcour≈øe, who judge by rea≈øon, not pa≈øsion, which ≈øo often makes the Crow ≈øeem white, the Bells to tink as the fools do think: and in confidence Reader that thy ingenuity is ≈øuch that no byas of intere≈øt will wheel thee narrow, and thy capacity able to draw thee from running wide of rea≈øon, the only mark men in civil games ≈øhould bowl at, I have taken the pains to pre≈øent thee with a map of Englands condition under her Monarchs, wherein thou may≈øt view how ju≈øtly Magna Charta is ca≈øt in our Governours teeths to beget a belief of their being
more tyrannous than our Kings were: admit it be not ob≈øerved in every tittle now, what are we the wor≈øe, when ≈øome fre≈øher and more appo≈øite remedy is applyed to heal us? let us con≈øider that it was con≈øtituted under another Government, and ≈øo cannot ≈øquare to the pre≈øent, and that the makers of it were but men, nay and ≈øuch as had not that roome to act in as we have, and ≈øo could not fore≈øee or at be≈øt provide for all that now providence hath wrought among≈øt us: but I ≈øhall not detain thee with a long Preface from the Book, wherein an ingenuous and rationall ≈øpirit will di≈øcern, that if our pre≈øent Governours had been bound up to former rules, we could never have attained that e≈øtate which now by Gods mercy and their prudence we enjoy, and may ≈øo ≈øtill if our own perver≈øne≈ø≈øe hinder us not. Truly that Fahle in Pliny of certain mon≈øtrous people in Africk which had one foot, and that ≈øo big, that they covered and ≈øhaded with it their whole body, may be a perfect embleme of our Kingly Government, which being at first in≈øtituted for a firm ba≈øis and prop to the body politick, what by the fatall ≈øloath and ≈øtupidity of the people, and the indu≈øtrious craft, and activity of Monarchs was turned top≈øie turvie, and had got ≈øo between heaven and us, that it wholly deprived us of that free light and happine≈ø≈øe which God and nature held forth unto us; and thus in ≈øtead of a ≈øupport was become a burden under the weight of which the whole groaned, nay was almo≈øt pre≈ø≈øed to death; but thou being a member and ≈øound, can≈øt not but be as ≈øen≈øible of this as I, and for dead ≈øle≈øh and rotten limbs, corro≈øives, and cuttings are onely proper, it will be weakne≈ø≈øe in me therefore to doubt of the plaudit to the Common wealth, ≈øo farewell till we meet in the book.

div.head: Anglo-Tyrannus, Or the Idea of a Norman MONARCH &c.
div.p: FAtall and Bloody have Crowns, and Scepters been in generall to all Nations, in particular to this in England, and that not only in regard of the ≈øtrife between competitours, who in pnrple gore deeply dyed their regall roabs, and by the ≈ølaughtered carca≈ø≈øes of their Rivals, and partakers, a≈øcended the Imperiall throne, but in re≈øpect of the iterated conte≈øts between Prerogative, and Liberty, the Kings aiming at uncontrolable ab≈øolutenes, the people claming their Native Freedome.

The verity of this a≈ø≈øertion we may ≈øee deeply imprinted in bloody Characters, throughout the whole ≈øeries of Engli≈øh hi≈øtory, yea ≈øo deeply, that it may even create an envy in us of the Turki≈øh happine≈ø≈øe, and beget a wi≈øh after their bondage, who though they go for ab≈øolute ≈ølaves, yet cannot ≈øhew ≈øuch dire effects of tyranny, as we and our ance≈øtors have felt and groaned under.

That policy of State (impious and inhumane enough) of de≈øtroying the younger Brothers of the Ottoman line, though decried by us and all who write Chri≈øtians, yet compared with our Monarches politick arts and actings, may
≈øeem to have been founded on the advice of their own, and mankinds better genius to prevent the efu≈øion of blood, and deliver millions from the ≈øhambles; there a few males of his own Family fall a victime to their Tyrant, when whole Hecatombs can ≈øcar≈øe appea≈øe the thir≈øty ambition of an Engli≈øh pretender; ther one hou≈øe ≈øuffers, here none e≈øcapes, as but to in≈øtance in oue conte≈øt between Henry the ≈øixth and Edward the fourth, wherein was fought ten bloody battles, be≈øides all le≈ø≈øer ≈øcirmi≈øhes, thou≈øands of Lords, Gentlemen, and Commons ≈ølaine, and one halfe of the Nation de≈øtroyed, to ≈øet up a King to trample upon the other; for in that quarrell between the Hou≈øes of Lanca≈øter and Yorke fell 80998. per≈øons, 2. Kings, 1. Prince, 10. Dukes, 2. Marque≈ø≈øes, 21. Earls, 2. Vi≈øcounts; 27. Lords, 1. Prior, 1. Iudge, 1‚ñ™ 39. Knights, 441. E≈øquiers: this hath been the happine≈ø≈ø and peace which a ≈øucce≈ø≈øive, and hereditary Monarchy hath afforded England.

For our liberty, we can indeed ≈øhew many of our Kings large, and good deeds, but few or none of their actions, their hands alwaies having been too hard for their Seals, Parchments, and Charters we purcha≈øed of them with the price of Millions, both in Blood, and Trea≈øure, but let us but pa≈øs by their promi≈øes, and view their performances, and we may ≈øet a≈øide Turkie, and term England the ≈ølave: and this appears in our Chronicles, where though in the Theorie and Sy≈øtem the Engli≈øh Government hath been limited, and bounded by good, and di≈øtingui≈øhing lawes, yet in the exerci≈øe and practic part of every Kings raign, we ≈øhall find it de≈øerve as bad a name as others, who are called mo≈øt ab≈øolute. The Poets fable of Tantalus hath been verified in us, who though we have been ≈øet up to the chinne in freedom, and have had liberty bobbing at our lips, yet never could we get a drop to ≈øquench our thir≈øts, or a ≈ønap to ≈øtay our ≈øtomacks, this being added to our ≈øufferings, to want in the mid≈øt of ≈øeeming abundance, and as the vulgar have it, to ≈øtarve in a Cooks ≈øhop, a trick tho≈øe Lords we term ab≈øolute were never ingenuous enough to torment their ≈ølaves with.

Were there then no more but this, we might well command
tho≈øe Roman and Turki≈øh Tyrants with a Cede Majoribus, to give place to ours: How much of a punie did thy wi≈øh ≈øavour dull Caligula, that all Rome had but one neck that thou mighte≈øt ≈ømite it off at a blow? How ≈øhort of art doth thy rage fall unskillfull Sultan with a Bow≈øtring or Scymiter to ≈ønach life from an offending ≈ølave? Behold, and blu≈øh you who weare the title of Ma≈øter Tyrants, at the Norman exactne≈ø≈øe, which hath thought it beneath a Princes anger to give ≈øudden death a quick riddance, and not worth the name of ≈ølavery unle≈ø≈øe he can make his va≈ø≈øals feel the lingring effects of his Tyranny: it was not enough for us to be ≈ølaves unle≈øs we knew it, le≈øt otherwi≈øe not de≈øiring freedom, we ≈øhould not have been ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of their power; we mu≈øt with Era≈ømus be hung between Heaven, and Hell, that we might ≈øee our lo≈ø≈øe as well as feel it; but yet this was not enough, ≈øomething mu≈øt be added to make their Tyranny mo≈øt exqui≈øite, for we could not enjoy this condition unle≈ø≈øe we paid ≈øoundly for it; how many Battles have been fought for a piece of Parchment to in≈øtruct us but with our mi≈øeries? and how many millions granted to our Kings but to play the Hocus-pocu≈ø≈øes and cheat us to our faces.

Happy and thrice happy may England call the condition of Turke, Ru≈ø≈øe, or Moor, who depending only upon their Tyrants wils, know no Law but their Commands, a head now and then paies the ≈øhot there, when two and twenty of the chiefe≈øt Lords heads mu≈øt off at once here, be≈øides thou≈øands of Gentlemen and Commons butchered, for but acting according to tho≈øe Lawes which their King and his predece≈ø≈øors had an hundred times ≈øworn to grant, and maintain inviolable; as but to in≈øtance in the Raign of Edw. 2. omitting the innumerable carca≈ø≈øes of Englands noble≈øt Sonnes, which have bin ≈øo often forced to rampire in parchment liberty from the fury of other Tyrant, and as their la≈øt wills to deliver a few writen Charters to their ≈øons, who were al≈øo to fight, and pay for them as they did, and be as much the better then too as they were: For to ≈øum up all, the≈øe our ≈øo dear liberties were of no other u≈øe than to drein our pur≈øes as well as veins, that when Englands generous bloud ≈øeemed encrea≈øed too
to tamely ≈øuffer Norman Lords to trample on her upon this pretence it might be let out; or when her Kings wanted mony, they might by the≈øe lures draw ≈øub≈øidies to their fi≈øts, and ≈øo hang them by till the next occa≈øion; but I humbly conceive that if our Ance≈øtors had taken that cour≈øe a Naturall once did, when he was cho≈øen to judg between a Cook, and a Country-man, and as their Kings fed them with a ≈øight of Liberty, ≈øupplied them againe with chinking of money, & have executed ju≈øtice without re≈øpect of per≈øons, they had in all probability diverted tho≈øe plagues, which the crying ≈øins of oppre≈ø≈øion and murder have brought down from Heaven upon this Nation. But let us de≈øcend from Generalls, and view but the Raign of Henry the third, the very Idea of Tyranny, and exact copie after which all other Kings have writ, e≈øpecially the la≈øt, and we ≈øhall not only behold the map of our Ance≈øtors mi≈øerie, and folly, but al≈øo perceive our own happine≈ø≈øe, and Gods mercie in not ≈øuffering us to be deluded and baffeled as they were.

In the mid≈øt of the civill flames kindled between Tyranny and liberty, King Iohn expiring, his ≈øonne Henry the third, a child of nine years of age, by the power of William Mar≈øhall Earl of Pembrook, and the con≈øent of mo≈øt of the Barons, a≈øcends the Throne: and here we may ob≈øerve the unadvi≈øed lenitie of the Engli≈øh Lords, who not con≈øidering what was bred in the bone would not ea≈øily out in the fle≈øh, ≈øo ea≈øily accepted of the Sonne, though the Father had plaid the Tyrant, and Traitor to the height, giving the Crown to the Pope (he would be a ≈ølave him≈øelf rather than they ≈øhould not) trampling upon the people, yea dete≈øting the whole Nation, as his grief becau≈øe Corne was ≈øo cheap when he thought he had wa≈øted al may make out: But Gods time was not come, and he was plea≈øed to ≈øet their example to guide po≈øterity from ≈øplitting on that Rock, I mean ≈øuch of them who when they have eyes will make u≈øe of them.

But to ≈øay the truth they were Lords, whom Kings knew ≈øo well to cajole, or at wor≈øt ≈øet ≈øo together by the ears, that they could command them into their traps at li≈øt; let but
one have that Earldome, the other this Lord≈øhip, and their turns were ≈øerved, others may ≈øhift for them≈øelves if they can; be≈øides it was none of their intere≈øt to ≈øtub up Tyranny by the roots, for then down had gon their branches too; for they knew that when that tree was feld, the Rooks ne≈øt, mu≈øt to ground with it; but we may be ≈øilent in this and give experience leave to ≈øpeak for us.

With this reprehen≈øion the King was netled, as his ≈øpeech the next Se≈øsion makes out, for though he promi≈øed amendment they would not beleeve him, and therefore prorogued the Parliament till Mid≈øummer, that they might ≈øee whether he would be as good as his word. Whereas ≈øervants ought not to judge their Ma≈øter, and Subjects their Prince, or hold them to their cond ‚Ä¢ tions. For the Servant is not above his Lord, nor the D ‚Ä¢ ≈øciple above his Ma≈øter; neither ≈øhould he be your King, but as your Servant, who ≈øhould ≈øo encline to your plea≈øure. Wherefore know I wil yeild to none of your de≈øires.

A brave ranting ≈øpeech, yet I hope it will not be denyed but they were evill Coun≈øellors, which put this into that Kings mouth, though they have been, who penned the late Kings Declarations, which were ≈øo like this ≈øpeech, as they could not be more, though Charls his Declarations had been ≈øpit out of Henries mouth; in both we may perceive the humour equally proud in the Kings, and jointly mi≈øchievous in their Coun≈øellors, the fir≈øt accounting their Subjects but their ≈ølaves, the ≈øecond making them≈øelves ≈øuch to curry favor with
their Lordly Ma≈øters; for let what palliations or di≈øguizes ≈øoever of evill Coun≈øellors be made to cover the ≈øhame of evill Princes, wi≈øe men know, and it hath alwayes been found by experience, that the Tyranny of the Kings, bears the fir≈øt, and the ≈ølavery of the in≈øtruments but the ≈øecond part, in the cau≈øality of the mi≈øchiefs, and that the≈øe Lions rampant, wil make u≈øe of none but A≈ø≈øes couchant, which are mo≈øt willing, as wel as mo≈øt able, to bear the load.

But to the ≈øtory.
